708944f-a.text:
North on Fifth Avenue from 5lst Street. Building marked x is William K. Vanderbilt Mansion. At extreme left are the twin Vanderbilt mansions. The first Church is St. Thomas's Protestant-Episcopal.
This later burned and was re-built.
1900.
Ewing Galloway, Photographer.

708945f.text:
Fifth Avenue north from 51st Street, showing Easter Sunday crowds. Two automobiles may be seen in this picture--one, in left foreground is south-bound, and is almost at N.W. corner of 51st Street. The other is north-bound, and is in right centre of picture.
1903.
Ewing Galloway, Photographer.

708948f-a.text:
Fifth Ave., west side, south from and including West 51st Street. Shown across the future site of the International Building, are three units of Rockefeller Center; R.C.A. Building (right), British Empire Building and La Nais on
Francaise.
May 15, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.

730194f-a.title: General view - 5th Avenue - Southwest.
730194f-a.text:
A general view of Rockefeller Center, looking southwestward from Fifth Ave. and West 51st Street, showing the new development under construction. The prominent building is the 70-story R.C.A. Building, on the west side of Rockefeller Plasa, from West 50th to West 49th Streets. On its right appears the 31-story R.K.0. Building, on the east side of Sixth Ave., from West 51st to West 50th Streets and preceding it
the International Music Hall.
June 14, 1933.
Brown Brothers.

713528f-a.text:
(1)
5lst Street, south side, west from west of Fifth Avenue, with the new Rockefeller Centre in the background.
July 2, 1933
P. L. Sperr
(2)
Another view from a point closer to Fifth Avenue. Note the Associated Press Building under construction in the vacant space shown in View 1 and to the rear of the Radio City Music Hall and R. K. O. Buildings. This new feature will be on the west side of (also new) Rockefeller Plaza, extending from 50th to 51st Street. On the left of View 1 appears a portion of the
huge International Building.
July 16, 1938
P. L. Sperr

708942f-b.text:
Home of General Cornelius Vanderbilt, N.W. corner of Fifth Avenue
and 5lst Street.
A similar house formerly adjoined it on the right, and the two were
known as the twin Vanderbilt houses.
Richard Morris Hunt was architect for the two.
April 9,1928.
P.L.Sperr,Photographer.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
A view mainly of the N.W. corner.
November 13, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.

708943f-a.text:
640 Fifth Avenue, at the N. W. corner of West 51st St., showing the Vanderbilt home, prior to its proposed demolition. This structure has been sold to the Astor real estete interests and who plan to erect a commercial two story structure here. It was the first of the numerous Vanderbilt houses in this area and now is the last. It was erected for Mrs. William H. Vanderbilt who became the dominant figure in society. Recognition here connoted social acceptance. General Cornelius Vanderbilt inherited
it at a later date.
October 26, 1940
Robert A. Knudtsen
221 E. 31at St., N.Y.C.
Neg #1005

708915f-a.text:
Fifth Avenue, east side, south from 52nd Street (right), showing prominently the steeples being added to St. Patricks Cathedral. This edifice was projected by Archbishop Hughs, and the cornerstone laid in 1858. It was opened in 1879. The steeples were added in 1888. On the right is the R. C. Orphan Asylum for Boys, occupying the 52nd to 5lst Street frontage. It was founded in 1825 and incorporated in 1852. The present buildings
were completed in 1851.
Date: 1888
Gift of Urbrock Collection

708940f-b.text:
(1)
Union Club, Fifth Avenue at the N.E. corner of 51st Street. This is the clubhouse built in 1902, and occupied by the Union Club from 1903 to 1933. The block in which it is situated used to be the site of the Roman Catholic Orphan
Asylum.
May 6, 1928.
Gift of P.  L. Sperr, Photographer.
(2)
The same, a closer view, and east on the north side of 51st
Street.
October 9, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
The same, as seen across clearance for Radio City.
October 2, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
